newshttp://edition.cnn.com/2003/WORLD/europe/10/30/concorde.nofly.reut/Concorde not to fly at air shows''CNN,'' 30 October 200330 June 201130 October 2003cite newshttp://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/2855044/Buffett-vehicle-to-follow-in-Concordes-slipstream.htmlBuffett vehicle to follow in Concorde's slipstream''The Daily Telegraph,'' 15 June 2003EdwardSimpkins15 June 2003LondonrefnQuote: "Airbus, the manufacturer of Concorde, has said it is becoming uneconomic to maintain the ageing craft and that it will no longer provide spare parts for it."N

It has been suggested that Concorde was not withdrawn for the reasons usually given but that it became apparent during the grounding of Concorde that the airlines could make more profit carrying first class passengers subsonically.cite webhttp://www.thetravelinsider.info/2003/0411.htmConcorde: An Untimely and Unnecessary Demise''Travel Insider,'' 200313 January 2010A lack of commitment to Concorde from Director of Engineering Alan MacDonald was cited as having undermined BAs resolve to continue operating Concorde.cite webhttp://www.concorde-spirit-tours.com/concorde.htmThe Betrayal of ConcordeDonald L.Pevsner''Concorde Spirit Tours''13 January 2010
article.heading: Air France
article.paragraph: multiple imagevertical 220 ConcordeCDG.jpg Air France Concorde at [[Paris-Charles de Gaulle Airport]] Aerospatial Concorde (6018513515).jpg Air France Concorde in [[Sinsheim Auto & Technik Museum|Auto & Technik Museum Sinsheim]] Air France made its final commercial Concorde landing in the United States in New York City from Paris on 30 May 2003.cite newsConcorde makes Final Flight from Paris to New York''Associated Press,'' 30 May 2003LaurentLemelcite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/2952594.stmFrench Concorde bids adieu''BBC News,'' 31 May 200331 May 2003Air France's final Concorde flight took place on 27 June 2003 when F-BVFC retired to Toulouse.cite webhttp://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-104484558.htmlJetting off''Daily Mirror,'' 28 June 200330 June 2011

Anauctionof Concorde parts and memorabilia for Air France was held atChristie'sin Paris on 15 November 2003; 1,300 people attended, and several lots exceeded their predicted values.cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/3246326.stm3,500 due at UK Concorde auction''BBC News,'' 30 November 200330 November 2003French Concorde F-BVFC was retired to Toulouse and kept functional for a short time after the end of service, in case taxi runs were required in support of the French judicial enquiry into the 2000 crash.cite webhttp://www.alacrastore.com/storecontent/Business-and-Industry/105669362Miscellaneous brief articles – Business & Industry''Flight International.'' 15 July 200330 June 2011The aircraft is now fully retired and no longer functional.cite webhttp://www.tourmag.com/Pourquoi-n-a-t-on-pas-sauve-le-Concorde_a7.htmlPourquoi n'a-t-on pas sauvé le Concorde?''TourMag.com,'' 24 March 201030 June 2011

French Concorde F-BTSD has been retired to the "Muse de l'Air" atParisLe Bourget Airportnear Paris, unlike the other museum Concordes, a few of the systems are being kept functional. For instance, the famous "droop nose" can still be lowered and raised. This led to rumours that they could be prepared for future flights for special occasions.cite newsThis is not a flight of fancy: Volunteers say Concorde can realise an Olympic dream if BA will help''The Times,'' 31 May 2006BenWebster

French Concorde F-BVFB currently rests at theSinsheim Auto & Technik MuseumAuto & Technik Museum SinsheimatSinsheim, Germany, after its last flight from Paris to Baden-Baden, followed by a spectacular transport toSinsheimvia barge and road. The museum also has aTupolev Tu-144on display  this is the only place where both supersonic airliners can be seen together.cite webhttp://sinsheim.technik-museum.de/concorde-f-bvfb/Museum Sinsheim''Museum Sinsheim''26 June 2010yeshttps://web.archive.org/20100512045534/http://sinsheim.technik-museum.de:80/concorde-f-bvfb12 May 2010

In 1989, Air France signed a letter of agreement to donate a Concorde to theNational Air and Space MuseuminWashington D.C.upon the aircraft's retirement. On 12 June 2003, Air France honoured that agreement, donating Concorde F-BVFA (serial 205) to the Museum upon the completion of its last flight. This aircraft was the first Air France Concorde to open service to Rio de Janeiro, Washington, D.C., and New York and had flown 17,824 hours. It is on display at the Smithsonian'sSteven F. Udvar-HazyCenter atDulles Airport.citation neededTag for entire paragraph, mainly agreement and other specifics.September 2015
article.heading: British Airways
article.paragraph: multiple imagevertical 220 G-BOAB in new home (8472694454).jpg BA Concorde G-BOAB in storage at [[London Heathrow Airport]]. This aircraft flew for 22,296 hours between its first flight in 1976 and its final flight in 2000. Concorde at Manchester Viewing Park.jpg BA Concorde G-BOAC in its hangar at [[Manchester Airport]] Aviation Viewing Park British Airways conducted a North American farewell tour in October 2003. G-BOAG visitedToronto Pearson International Airporton 1 October, after which it flew to New Yorks John F. Kennedy International Airport.cite newshttp://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/thestar/access/417072421.html?didsConcorde's supersonic swan song; Star writer aboard for jet's farewell trip to Toronto Transatlantic sound-breaker a vision of grace''Toronto Star,'' 2 October 2003MarcAtchison2 October 2003G-BOAD visitedBostonsLogan International Airporton 8 October, and G-BOAG visitedWashington Dulles International Airporton 14 October.cite webhttp://goliath.ecnext.com/coms2/gi_0199-3250817/Final-flight-British-Airways-Concorde.htmlFinal flight: British Airways Concorde lands locally for last time''Washington Post,'' 15 October 2003TomRamstackyeshttps://web.archive.org/20150510192947/http://goliath.ecnext.com/coms2/gi_0199-3250817/Final-flight-British-Airways-Concorde.html10 May 2015It has been claimed that G-BOADs flight fromLondon Heathrow AirportLondon Heathrowto Boston set a transatlantic flight record of 3 hours, 5 minutes, 34 seconds.cite newshttp://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-24654137_ITMConcorde establishes London-to-U.S. record''America's Intelligence Wire,'' 9 October 200330 June 20119 October 2003yeshttps://web.archive.org/20120127041801/http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-24654137_ITM27 January 2012However the fastest transatlantic flight was fromNew YorkJFK airport to Heathrow on 7 February 1996, taking 2 hours, 52 minutes, 59 seconds; 90 seconds less than a record set in April 1990.cite journalhttp://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1996/1996%20-%200341.htmlSupersonic recordFlight International14–20 February 19965"Exhibits: Concorde".Intrepidmuseum.org.Retrieved 6 March 2011.

In a week of farewell flights around theUnited Kingdom, Concorde visitedBirminghamon 20 October,Belfaston 21 October,Manchesteron 22 October,Cardiffon 23 October, andEdinburghon 24 October. Each day the aircraft made a return flight out and back intoHeathrowto the cities, often overflying them at low altitude.cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/england/bristol/somerset/3238674.stmLast Concorde lands''BBC News,''30 June 201127 November 2003cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/3205915.stmConcorde enjoys Cardiff farewell''BBC News.'' 23 October 200323 October 2003cite webhttp://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B0001DI57GConcorde – The Farewell – A collection of the final flights of the last days of Concorde''Simply Media,'' 19 April 200430 June 2011On 22 October, both Concorde flight BA9021C, a special fromManchester, and BA002 fromNew Yorklanded simultaneously on both of Heathrow's runways. On 23 October 2003,Elizabeth II of the United Kingdomthe Queenconsented to the illumination ofWindsor Castle, an honour reserved for state events and visiting dignitaries, as Concorde's last west-bound commercial flight departed London.cite webhttp://www.rockawave.com/news/2003-10-31/Front_Page/028.htmlThe Concorde Makes A ComebackBrianMagoolaghan''Wave of Long Island,'' 31 October 200330 June 2011

British Airwaysretired its Concorde fleet on 24 October 2003.cite webhttp://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A11477-2003Oct24.htmlFinal Concorde flight lands at HeathrowJillLawless''Associated Press,'' 26 October 2003G-BOAG left New York to a fanfare similar to that given for Air Frances F-BTSD, while two more made round trips, G-BOAF over theBay of Biscay, carrying VIP guests including former Concorde pilots, and G-BOAE to Edinburgh. The three aircraft then circled over London, having received special permission to fly at low altitude, before landing in sequence at Heathrow. The captain of the New York to London flight was Mike Bannister.cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/3211053.stmEnd of an era for Concorde''BBC News''24 October 2003The final flight of a Concorde in the US occurred on 5 November 2003 when G-BOAG flew from New York'sJohn F. Kennedy International AirportKennedy Airportto Seattle'sBoeing Fieldto join theMuseum of Flight's permanent collection. The plane was piloted by Mike Bannister and Les Broadie who claimed a flight time of three hours, 55 minutes and 12 seconds, a record between the two cities.cite webhttp://www.seattlepi.com/local/article/Thousands-welcome-Concorde-to-Seattle-1128999.phpThousands welcome Concorde to Seattleseattlepi.comThe museum had been pursuing a Concorde for their collection since 1984.cite webhttp://rbogash.com/Concorde.htmlConcordeRobert Bogashrbogash.comThe final flight of a Concorde world-wide took place on 26 November 2003 with a landing at Filton, Bristol, UK.cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/bristol/3238674.stmBBC News: Last Concorde lands''BBC News,''27 November 2003

All of BA's Concorde fleet have been grounded, drained of hydraulic fluid and their airworthiness certificates withdrawn. Jock Lowe, ex-chief Concorde pilot and manager of the fleet estimated in 2004 that it would cost 1015 million to make G-BOAF airworthy again.BA maintain ownership and have stated that they will not fly again due to a lack of support from Airbus.cite webhttp://www.britishairways.com/concorde/faq.html#17Will Concorde ever come out of retirement – e.g. for a Coronation flypast or airshows?''British Airways''14 January 2010On 1 December 2003,Bonhamsheld an auction of British Airways Concorde artifacts, including a nose cone, atOlympia Exhibition CentreKensington Olympiain London.cite newshttp://www.usatoday.com/travel/news/2003-12-02-concorde_x.htmConcorde nose cone sells for half-million at auction''USA Today,'' 12 December 200330 June 20112 December 2003cite webhttp://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-87889450.htmlConcorde Memorabilia Auction''Getty Images,'' 1 December 200330 June 2011Proceeds of around 750,000 were raised, with the majority going to charity. G-BOAD is currently on display at theIntrepid Sea, Air & Space Museumin New York.In 2007, BA announced that the advertising spot at Heathrow where a 40% scale model of Concorde was located would not be retained; the model is now on display at theBrooklands Museum.cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/london/6509667.stmHeathrow Concorde model removed''BBC News''30 March 2007
article.heading: Restoration
article.paragraph: Although only used for spares after being retired from test flying and trials work in 1981, Concorde G-BBDG was dismantled and transported by road fromFiltonthen restored from essentially a shell at theBrooklands MuseuminSurrey.cite webhttp://www.concordeproject.com/The Brooklands Concorde Project''Brooklands Museum''15 January 2010

One of the youngest Concordes (F-BTSD) is on display atMuse de l'AirLe Bourget Air and Space Museumin Paris. In February 2010, it was announced that the museum and a group of volunteer Air France technicians intend to restore F-BTSD so it can taxi under its own power.cite webhttp://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2010/02/05/338114/air-france-concorde-to-taxi-again-under-own-power.htmlAir France Concorde to taxi again under own power''Flightglobal,'' 5 February 20105 February 2010In May 2010, it was reported that the British Save Concorde Group and French Olympus 593 groups had begun inspecting the engines of a Concorde at the French museum; their intent is to restore the airliner to a condition where it can fly in demonstrations.cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/8712806.stmWork starts in £15m plan to get Concorde Flying''BBC News''29 May 201029 May 2010Save Concorde Group hoped to get F-BTSD flying for the 2012 London Olympics, but this never happened. The work for restoring F-BTSD to operating condition as of September 2015 is currently not very well known, and it is still being housed in Le Bourget as a museum exhibit. In 2015 the organisation Club Concorde announced that it had raised funds of 120 million for a static displaycite webhttp://www.avweb.com/avwebflash/news/Group-Plans-To-Fly-Concorde-By-2019-224879-1.htmlGroup Plans To Fly Concorde By 2019avweb.comand to buy the Concorde at Le Bourget, restore it and return it to service as a heritage aircraft for air displays and charter hire by 2019, to coincide with the 50th anniversary of Concorde's first flight.cite webhttp://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/sep/18/supersonic-breakthrough-concorde-could-fly-again-within-four-yearsSupersonic breakthrough: Concorde could fly again within four yearsColdwellWill18 September 2015[[theguardian.com]]18 September 2015

In July 2015 it was reported that planning permission had been granted for the construction of the museum atBristol Filton Airportto house G-BOAF the last Concorde where it is intended to form a key exhibit of the newBristol Aviation Heritage Museum.cite newsConcorde museum wins planning permissionhttp://www.bristolpost.co.uk/Concorde-museum-wins-planning-permission/story-27449949-detail/story.html20 July 2015Bristol Post20 July 2015
article.heading: Return to service plan
article.paragraph: In September 2015 it was publicly revealedhttp://www.telegraph.co.uk/luxury/travel/83904/concorde-flights-planned-to-resume-and-aircraft-proposed-for-display-in-london.htmlthat the Concorde Club had secured over 160 million to return an aircraft to service.http://www.dailymail.co.uk/travel/travel_news/article-3239952/Concorde-set-return-skies-Supersonic-jet-used-charter-flights-2019.html

Concorde Club president Paul James said: The main obstacle to any Concorde project to date has been Wheres the money? a question we heard ad nauseam, until we found an investor. Now that money is no longer the problem its over to those who can help us make it happen.http://www.clubconcorde.co.uk/potential-return-to-flight-2015.phpThe organisation aims to buy the Concorde currently on display at Le Bourget airport. A tentative date of 2019 has been put forward for the first flight - 50 years after its maiden journey.http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/sep/18/supersonic-breakthrough-concorde-could-fly-again-within-four-years
article.heading: Operators

Singapore Airlines(1 on short termwet lease)

article.heading: Aircraft on display
Comparable aircraft

link.target: File:Russian Tu-144LL SST Flying Laboratory Takeoff at Zhukovsky Air Development Center.jpg
link.part: Tu-144FL as a research aircraft forNASAin 1997
Tu-144 and Concorde inSinsheim Auto & Technik MuseumAuto & Technik Museum Sinsheim

article.paragraph: The only supersonic airliner in direct competition with Concorde was the SovietTupolev Tu-144, nicknamed "Concordski" by Western European journalists for its outward similarity to Concorde.cite newshttp://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,912014,00.htmlSoviet Union: Christening the Concordski''Time,'' 14 November 197730 June 201114 November 1977It had been alleged that Sovietespionageefforts had resulted in the theft of Concorde blueprints, ostensibly to assist in the design of the Tu-144.Gordon, Yefim.Tupolev Tu-144. London: Midland, 2006. ISBN 1-85780-216-0.As a result of a rushed development programme, the first Tu-144 prototype was substantially different from the preproduction machines, but both were cruder than Concorde. The Tu-144Shad a significantly shorter range than Concorde, due to its low-bypass turbofan engines.cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/1328132.stm'Concordski' designer dies''BBC News,'' 13 May 200113 May 2001The aircraft had poor control at low speeds because of a simpler supersonic wing design; in addition the Tu-144 requireddrogue parachutebraking parachutesto land while Concorde used anti-lock brakes.cite newshttp://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?resSoviet SST, in Its First Flight to the West, Arrives in Paris for Air ShowJohn LHess''The New York Times,'' 26 May 197130 June 201126 May 1971The Tu-144 had two crashes, one at the1973 Paris Air Show crash1973 Paris Air Show,cite webhttp://news.google.co.uk/newspapers?idSoviet SST stalls, dives into townsGeorgeDeruaz''St. Petersburg Times,'' 4 June 197330 June 2011cite webhttp://news.google.co.uk/newspapers?idPride of Soviet air fleet explodes during exhibition''Sarasota Journal,'' 4 June 197330 June 2011and another during a pre-delivery test flight in May 1978.cite newshttp://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/659730132.html?didsRussia confirms crash of Supersonic Airliner in test: Latest failure of Trouble-plagued TU-144 seen as blow to Soviet hopes of expanding industry''Los Angeles Times,'' 27 October 1978DanFisher27 October 1978cite webhttp://aviation-safety.net/database/record.php?idASN Aircraft accident Tupolev 144D CCCP-77111 YegoryevskFlight Safety Foundation1 July 2011

Later production Tu-144 versions were more refined and competitive. They had retractablecanardsfor better low-speed control, turbojet engines providing nearly the fuel efficiency and range of Concordecite webhttp://en.rian.ru/analysis/20080603/109170103.htmlThe Tu-144: the future that never was''RIA Novosti,'' 3 January 200830 June 2011and a top speed of Mach 2.35. Passenger service commenced in November 1977, but after the 1978 crash the aircraft was taken out of service. The aircraft had an inherently unsafe structural design as a consequence of an automated production method chosen to simplify and speed up manufacturing.Fridlyander, Iosif. "Sad Epic of the Tu-144."Messenger of Russian Academy of Sciences, 1, 2002 (in Russian: .. ," -144", , 1, 2002.

The American designs, theBoeing 2707and theLockheed L-2000, were to have been larger, with seating for up to 300 people.cite webhttp://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1964/1964%20-%200377.htmlThe United States SST Contenders''Flight International,'' 13 February 1964234–23530 June 2011Winchester 2005, p. 84.Running a few years behind Concorde, the Boeing 2707 was redesigned to a cropped delta layout; the extra cost of these changes helped to kill the project.cite newshttp://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?resThe Russians Lead With the SST...Richard DLyons''The New York Times,'' 5 January 196930 June 20115 January 1969The operation of US military aircraft such as theXB-70 ValkyrieandB-58 Hustlerhad shown that sonic booms were quite capable of reaching the ground,cite newshttp://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/574189232.html?didsB-58's Sonic Boom Rattles Kentuckians''Chicago Daily Tribune,'' 19 December 196130 June 201119 December 1961and the experience from theOklahoma City sonic boom testsled to the same environmental concerns that hindered the commercial success of Concorde. The American government cancelled the project in 1971, after having spent more than $1 billion.cite newshttp://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,944291,00.htmlThe Nation: Showdown on the SST''Time,'' 29 May 197130 June 201129 March 1971

The only other large supersonic aircraft comparable to Concorde arestrategic bombers, principally the RussianTupolev Tu-22Tu-22,Tupolev Tu-22MTu-22M,Myasishchev M-50M-50(experimental),Sukhoi T-4T-4(experimental),Tupolev Tu-160Tu-160and the AmericanNorth American XB-70 ValkyrieXB-70(experimental),Rockwell B-1 LancerB-1.citation neededApril 2014
article.heading: Impact
Environmental
article.paragraph: Before Concordes flight trials, developments in the civil aviation industry were largely accepted by governments and their respective electorates. Opposition to Concordes noise, particularly on the east coast of the United States,cite newshttp://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,918012,00.htmlHere Comes the Concorde, Maybe''Time,'' 16 February 197630 June 201116 February 1976cite journalhttp://heinonline.org/HOL/LandingPage?collectionLegal and Environmental ramifications of the ConcordeRobert M.AllenJ. Air L. & Com., 197630 June 2011forged a new political agenda on both sides of the Atlantic, with scientists and technology experts across a multitude of industries beginning to take the environmental and social impact more seriously.cite journalhttp://md1.csa.com/partners/viewrecord.php?requesterRecent studies into Concorde noise reductionHock, R.R. Hawkins''AGARD Noise Mech,'' 19741430 June 2011cite journalhttp://heinonline.org/HOL/LandingPage?collectionAircraft Noise: Federal pre-emption of Local Control, Concorde and other recent casesJoshua A.Muss''J. Air L. & Com,'' 197730 June 2011Although Concorde led directly to the introduction of a general noise abatement programme for aircraft flying out of John F. Kennedy Airport, many found that Concorde was quieter than expected,partly due to the pilots temporarily throttling back their engines to reduce noise during overflight of residential areas.Endres 2001, p 90.Even before revenue flights started it had been claimed that Concorde was quieter than several aircraft then in service.cite journal10.1108/eb035013http://www.emeraldinsight.com/Insight/viewContentItem.do?contentTypeReducing noise with type 28 nozzleAircraft Engineering and Aerospace Technology1973454, 197314''MCB UP''In 1971 BAC's technical director was quoted "It is certain on present evidence and calculations that in the airport context, production Concordes will be no worse than aircraft now in service and will in fact be better than many of them."Aviation Daily18 Feb 1971 p263

Concorde produced nitrogen oxides in its exhaust, which, despite complicated interactions with other ozone-depleting chemicals, are understood to result in degradation to theozone layerat thestratospherestratosphericaltitudes it cruised.cite journal10.1126/science.270.5233.70http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/abstract/sci;270/5233/70Emission Measurements of the Concorde Supersonic Aircraft in the Lower StratosphereFahey, D. W.Science19952707052331995Sci...270...70FetalIt has been pointed out that other, lower-flying, airliners produce ozone during their flights in the troposphere, but vertical transit of gases between the layers is restricted. The small fleet meant overall ozone-layer degradation caused by Concorde was negligible.David W. Fahey, of theNational Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, found that to produce a drop in stratospheric ozone of 1 to 2% would require a fleet of 500 supersonic aircraft to be operated. Dr. Fahey stated that this would not be a limiting factor for furthersupersonic transportdevelopment."Increase in supersonic jets could be threat to ozone U-2 plane trails Concorde, studies exhaust particles."Baltimore Sun,October 8, 1995.

Concordes technical leap forward boosted the publics understanding of conflicts between technology and the environment as well as awareness of the complex decision analysis processes that surround such conflicts.cite journalhttp://heinonline.org/HOL/LandingPage?collectionDecision Analysis in Environmental Decisionmaking: Improving the Concorde BalanceJonAnderson''HeinOnline,'' 197830 June 2011In France, the use ofnoise barrieracoustic fencingalongsideTGVtracks might not have been achieved without the 1970s controversy over aircraft noise.cite web''Environmental Science and Engineering,'' November 2001http://www.esemag.com/1101/1101ed.htmlTrain à grande vitesse causes distressyeshttps://web.archive.org/20100116124028/http://www.esemag.com:80/1101/1101ed.html16 January 2010In the UK, theCampaign to Protect Rural EnglandCPREhas issuedTranquillity#Mapping tranquillitytranquillity mapssince 1990.cite webhttp://www.cpre.org.uk/campaigns/landscape/tranquillity/national-and-regional-tranquillity-mapsNational and regional tranquillity maps''Campaign to Protect Rural England''25 April 2010
Some sources say Concorde typically flewconvert17mpgu.s.per passenger (100 passengers were maximum capacity).cite webhttp://www.concordesst.com/powerplant.htmlCONCORDE SST : Powerplantconcordesst.com
article.heading: Public perception

link.part: Parade flight at QueensGolden Jubilee of Elizabeth IIGolden Jubileein June 2002

article.paragraph: Concorde was normally perceived as a privilege of the rich, but special circular or one-way (with return by other flight or ship) charter flights were arranged to bring a trip within the means of moderately well-off enthusiasts.cite webhttp://www.alacrastore.com/storecontent/Business-and-Industry/24962872British Airways Concorde is expected to begin flying passengers again in next 6 weeks''Dallas Morning News,'' 23 August 200130 June 2011

The aircraft was usually referred to by the British as simply "Concorde".cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/in_depth/uk/2003/concorde_retirement/default.stmFarewell to Concorde''BBC News,'' 15 August 200715 January 201015 August 2007In France it was known as "le Concorde" due to "le", the definite article,Oxford Language Dictionaries Online  French Resources: Glossary of Grammatical Termsused inFrench grammarto introduce the name of a ship or aircraft,Centre National de Ressources Textuelles et Lexicales  Dfinition de LE, LA: article dfini, II.3and the capital being used to distinguish aproper namefrom acommon nounof the same spelling.Reverso Dictionnaire: La majuscule dans les noms propres("Capital letters within proper names")In French, the common nounconcordemeans "agreement, harmony, or peace".refn'''concorde''' ''s.f.'' concord, unity, harmony, peace.Ferrar 1980, p. 114.NConcordes pilots and British Airways in official publications often refer to Concorde both in the singular and plural as "she" or "her".cite webhttp://www.britishairways.com/travel/concvidhome/public/en_gbCelebrate Concorde: videos''British Airways''15 January 2010cite webhttp://www.youtube.com/watch?vDocumentary of British Airways Concorde introduction''youtube.com''refnQuote: [[Raymond Baxter]] commentating as Concorde flies for first time: "She rolls ... She flies!"N

As a symbol of national pride, an example from the BA fleet made occasionalflypastsat selected Royal events, major air shows and other special occasions, sometimes in formation with theRed Arrows.cite webhttp://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-62676656.htmlRed Arrows fly into Scotland''Daily Record,'' 12 June 200030 June 2011cite newshttp://www.telegraph.co.uk/education/3297816/Million-turn-out-to-crown-Queens-Jubilee.htmlMillion turn out to crown Queen's Jubilee''Daily Telegraph,'' 4 June 2002London1 April 20104 June 2002On the final day of commercial service, public interest was so great that grandstands were erected at Heathrow Airport. Significant numbers of people attended the final landings; the event received widespread media coverage.cite newshttp://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1444939/Chaos-fear-at-Concorde-farewell.htmlChaos fear at Concorde farewell''Daily Telegraph,'' 24 October 2003SandraLaville24 October 2003London

In 2006, 37 years after its first test flight, Concorde was announced the winner of the Great British Design Quest organised by the BBC and theDesign Museum. A total of 212,000 votes were cast with Concorde beating design icons such as theMini,mini skirt,Jaguar E-type,Tube mapand theSupermarine Spitfire.cite newshttp://news.independent.co.uk/uk/this_britain/article351851.eceConcorde beats Tube map to become Britain's favourite designLouiseJury''The Independent,'' 17 March 2006London17 March 2006
article.heading: Special missions
article.paragraph:
multiple imagevertical 220 Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip disembark from a British Airways Concorde.jpg [[Elizabeth II|The Queen]] and [[Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh|The Duke of Edinburgh]] disembark Concorde in 1991.
Heads of France and the United Kingdom flew Concorde many times.cite webhttp://www.aparchive.com/metadata/Concorde-Clipreel-Part-9/7ece56f04f3cf534e71bd4b4454b8d9e?searchfilterConcorde Clipreel: Part 9 - AP Archiveaparchive.comcite webhttp://heritageconcorde.com/passenger-experience-2/famous-concorde-passengers-2Heritage ConcordeHeritage Concordecite webhttp://www.aviation-news.co.uk/archive/concordeChronology.htmlAviation News Magazine - Concorde chronologyaviation-news.co.ukPresidentsGeorges Pompidou,cite webhttp://www.aparchive.com/metadata/Concorde-Clipreel-Part-8/3e56c7b758bb1e049f6763222b9e93c2?searchfilterConcorde Clipreel: Part 8 - AP Archiveaparchive.comcite webhttp://www.gettyimages.co.uk/detail/news-photo/french-president-georges-pompidou-at-the-microphone-in-the-news-photo/3375737French President Georges Pompidou at the microphone in the cockpit of...KeystoneGetty ImagesValry Giscard d'Estaingcite webhttp://www.newspapers.com/newspage/29590760/The Amarillo Globe-Times from Amarillo, Texas · Page 31Newspapers.comcite webhttp://www.newspapers.com/newspage/49473870/The Ottawa Journal from Ottawa, · Page 29Newspapers.comThe New York Times. Giscard Arrives for Talks With Fordcite webhttp://hansard.millbanksystems.com/lords/1976/may/27/the-queens-visit-to-north-americaTHE QUEEN'S VISIT TO NORTH AMERICAmillbanksystems.comandFranois Mitterrandcite webhttp://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/7733286/Francois-Mitterrand.htmlFrançois Mitterrand9 January 1996Telegraph.co.ukcite webhttp://articles.latimes.com/1988-11-27/news/mn-1081_1_soviet-spaceFrench Cosmonaut Aboard : Mitterrand Sees a Soviet Space LaunchlatimesReuter. President Francois Mitterrand prepared today to fly by ConcordeThe New York Times. Miitterrand's travels are well received back homeregularly used Concorde as French flagman aircraft in foreign visits. QueenElizabeth IIand Prime MinistersEdward Heath,Jim Callaghan,Margaret Thatcher,John Major,Tony Blairtook Concorde in some charter flights such as the Queen's trips to Barbados on her Silver Jubilee in 1977, in 1987 and in 2003, to Middle East in 1984, to the United States in 1991, etc.cite webhttp://www.burleighphoto.com/pages/stk-qe77/qe2.htmQueen Elizabeth II Silver Jubilee in Barbados ends with her first flight on Concorde on a record setting flight back to London Heathrow.CraigBurleigh200816 January 2010cite webhttp://www.royal.gov.uk/MonarchAndCommonwealth/TheQueenandBarbados/Royalvisits.aspxQueen and Barbados: Royal visitsQueen Elizabeth IIJanuary 201016 January 2010cite webhttp://www.concordesst.com/history/00s.htmlCONCORDE SST : TIMELINE -90'sconcordesst.comBarbados Concorde Experience, museum

Pope John Paul IIflew Concorde in May 1989.cite webhttp://www.concorde-art-world.com/html/f-btsc.htmlConcorde F-BTSC - French Production Test Aircraft11 May 2014Concorde Art WorldThe British Prime Minister flew in a British Airways Concorde (G-BOAC) toSan Juan, Puerto RicoSan Juanfor the second G-6 Economic Summit, held in the United States and hosted byPresidentGerald Fordat theDorado Beach Hotelin Dorado, Puerto Rico on June 2728, 1976.Citation neededMay 2014

Concorde sometimes made special flights for its demonstration, for exhibit on airshows (Farnborough AirshowFarnborough,Paris Air ShowParis-LeBourget,MAKS (air show)MAKS, etc.) and other expositions, for taking part in parades and celebrations (as ex., of Zrich airport anniversary in 1998), for private charters (as ex., many times by President ofZaireMobutu Sese Seko), for promo-advertising of companies (Oki Electric IndustryOKI, etc.), for Olympic torch relays (1992 Winter Olympics1992 Winter Olympics in Albertville), for observing ofsolar eclipse, etc.cite newsTharoorIshaanMobutu Sese Sekohttp://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,2097426_2097427_2097458,00.htmlTop 15 Toppled DictatorsTime Magazine30 April 201320 October 2011cite bookShawKarlPower Mad!Šílenství mocných20052004MetaforaPrahaCzech80-7359-002-647., 58.cite webhttp://www.concorde-jet.com/e_photos.php?refFinding the Right Arizona InsuranceConcorde Insurancecite webhttp://www.aparchive.com/metadata/Concorde-Clipreel-Part-14/a1e5b8386694bfb4b427492aaafb6e0e?searchfilterConcorde Clipreel: Part 14 - AP Archiveaparchive.comcite webhttp://www.concorde-spirit-tours.com/Concorde Spirit Toursconcorde-spirit-tours.com
article.heading: Records
article.paragraph: The fastest transatlantic airliner flight was fromJohn F. Kennedy International AirportNew York JFKtoLondon Heathrowon 7 February 1996 by British Airways' G-BOAD in 2 hours, 52 minutes, 59 seconds from takeoff to touchdown aided by a 175 mph (282 km/h) tailwind.cite newshttp://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_productReuters News ServiceSST makes record flight''St Louis Post,'' 9 February 199630 June 20119 February 1996On 13 February 1985, a Concorde charter flight flew from London Heathrow toSydney AirportSydneyon the opposite side of the worldin a time of 17 hours, 3 minutes and 45 seconds, including refuelling stops.cite webhttp://www.concorde-art-world.com/html/record_breaker.htmlConcorde Supersonic Airliner - Record Breakerconcorde-art-world.comcite webhttp://concordesst.yuku.com/topic/4886/List-of-Concorde-RecordsList of Concorde Records in Main Discussion area ForumYukucite webhttps://news.google.com/newspapers?nidThe Sydney Morning Herald - Google News Archive Searchgoogle.com

Concorde also set other records, including the officialFdration Aronautique InternationaleFAI"Westbound Around the World" and "Eastbound Around the World" world air speed records.cite webhttp://www.allbusiness.com/transportation/air-transportation-airports/7142582-1.htmlAir France Concorde sets round-the-world speed record''Business Wire,'' 16 August 199530 June 2011Dead linkApril 2012H3llBotOn 1213 October 1992, in commemoration of the 500th anniversary of Columbus first New World landing, Concorde Spirit Tours (USA) chartered Air France Concorde F-BTSD and circumnavigated the world in 32 hours 49 minutes and 3 seconds, from Lisbon, Portugal, including six refuelling stops atSanto Domingo,Acapulco,Honolulu, Guam,Bangkok, andBahrain.cite newsFrench Concorde to attempt round-the-world record''Anchorage Daily News,'' 12 October 1992

The eastbound record was set by the same Air France Concorde (F-BTSD) under charter to Concorde Spirit Toursin the USA on 1516 August 1995. This promotional flight circumnavigated the world from New York/JFK International Airport in 31 hours 27 minutes 49 seconds, including six refuelling stops atToulouse,Dubai, Bangkok, Andersen AFB inGuam, Honolulu, andAcapulco.cite newsConcorde jets occupants on record ride''Deseret News''17 August 1995By its 30th flight anniversary on 2 March 1999 Concorde had clocked up 920,000 flight hours, with more than 600,000 supersonic, many more than all of the other supersonic aircraft in the Western world combined.cite newsRolls-Royce SNECMA Olympus''Janes,'' 25 July 2000

On its way to the Museum of Flight in November 2003, G-BOAG set a New York City-to-Seattle speed record of 3 hours, 55 minutes, and 12 seconds.cite webhttp://www.museumofflight.org/aircraft/concordeConcordeMuseum of Flight21 August 2011
